awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Na,K,Cl Cotransporters in Mosquito Epithelial Transport - Connecting Molecules to Physiology
awd_abstract_narration:
This research explores the mechanisms that mosquitoes use to regulate their salt and water balance under the challenging conditions they face during their lifecycles.  Most mosquito larvae live in freshwater and must absorb salt to counteract the tendency for salt to diffuse out of their bodies.  In contrast, adult female mosquitoes must expel large amounts of salt after they engorge on a salty blood meal.  The specific focus of this project is on three mosquito proteins that help carry salts such as sodium, potassium, and chloride into or out of the body.  One of these proteins is closely related to proteins in humans and other vertebrate animals that are important to salt and water balance. Thus, studying the mosquito version of this protein may uncover fundamental properties of salt-transporting proteins that are shared between vertebrates and insects. The other two proteins are only found in mosquitoes and other insects, and have not been characterized in any animal. Gaining a better understanding of these novel insect proteins may be especially useful in developing strategies to control mosquitoes and other insect pests, since it may be possible to target them without affecting vertebrate proteins. This research project will develop new tools for researchers to assess where these proteins are located in the mosquito body, what salts they carry, and what chemicals can interfere with their function. Additionally, three undergraduate students and one graduate student will receive closely mentored research experiences.  

Mosquitoes must secrete and absorb ions differently depending on their life stage, sex, and environment. Three proteins from the yellow fever mosquito Aedes aegypti have sequence similarity to vertebrate Na+-dependent cation-chloride cotransporters (CCCs), which participate in both ion absorption and secretion. This work will produce critical reagents and refine procedures that are necessary to begin linking the molecular properties of the mosquito CCCs to their transport functions and whole-animal physiological roles. The first objective is to develop isoform-specific antibodies that recognize and differentiate among each of the three mosquito CCCs. The selectivity of the antibodies will be evaluated by comparing their reactivity among different mosquito tissues and developmental stages, mosquitoes in which expression of a specific CCC has been silenced by RNA interference, and in Xenopus oocytes injected with cRNAs encoding a particular CCC. The second objective is to confirm functional heterologous expression of each mosquito CCC in Xenopus oocytes. Functional expression of the CCCs will be evaluated using standard radioisotope uptake assays and newly developed non-radioactive methods. Findings from the proposed work may also be useful in identifying novel molecular targets to aid in the development of new insecticides for the control of insect disease vectors and agricultural pests. Three undergraduate students and one graduate student will receive mentored research training and the principal investigators will initiate community outreach programs.

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Ohio Agricultural Research and Development Center

por.por_cntn:
The yellow fever mosquito, Aedes aegypti, is a vector for viruses that cause human diseases including yellow fever, dengue, chikungunya, and Zika viruses. Aedes aegypti and other mosquitos face differing salt and water balance challenges across their life cycle. Larval mosquitoes live in freshwater or brackish water and therefore need to retain or replace salts lost by diffusion to the environment. In contrast, adults face water loss by evaporation and adult female mosquitoes need to secrete salt rapidly after they take a blood meal. Using Aedes aegypti as a model system, we explored the role of the sodium-dependent cation-chloride cotransporters in the salt and water balance of mosquitoes. These membrane proteins carry salt across cell membranes, contributing to its movement into and out of the body.

We identified three Aedes aegypti genes that code for sodium-dependent cation-chloride cotransporters. Whereas one of these transporters is closely related to transporters that have been well-characterized in fruit flies and vertebrates, the other two transporters (aeCCC2 and aeCCC3) are part of an insect-specific group that has not been characterized in any species. Studies of these insect-specific sodium-dependent cation-chloride cotransporters have the potential to uncover fundamental structure-function properties of the transporters in this family and to shed light on their evolutionary history. Moreover, the insect-specific transporters may be attractive targets for insecticides since vertebrates lack closely-related transporters.

To characterize the roles of Aedes aegypti sodium-dependent cation-chloride cotransporters in mosquito salt and water balance, we evaluated their expression pattern in tissues that transport salt. We found aeCCC2 highly expressed in adult hindgut tissue and aeCCC3 primarily expressed in larval anal papillae. Since both tissues are known to absorb ions into the body, these localizations suggest that aeCCC2 and aeCCC3 may play roles in salt uptake. Additionally, we developed antibodies that specifically recognize each transporter and used the antibodies to precisely identify the location of the transporters. In the mosquito renal tubule, we found aeCCC2 located on the side of the membrane that faces the internal body fluids of mosquito larvae, a position that suggests it may have a role in salt secretion. Together, these findings point towards functional roles of sodium-dependent cation-chloride cotransporters that may vary between tissues and developmental stages and may differ from those well-described in other animals.

We began evaluating the transport function of the Aedes aegypti transporters by expressing them in frog oocytes and measuring uptake of lithium, which serves as a tracer for sodium movement, and rubidium, which serves as a tracer for potassium movement. Our findings suggest that the insect-specific transporters may have different ion transport properties than the well-characterized vertebrate transporters that carry sodium, potassium, and chloride. In summary, these results provide the groundwork for further characterization of the location and transport properties of the insect-specific sodium-dependent cation-chloride cotransporters.

This project strengthened a collaborative relationship between investigators at a large state university a small liberal arts college. Across the two years of the project, one post-doctoral fellow, thirteen undergraduate students, and one high school student received mentored research experiences. Also, the principal investigator developed and led scientific writing workshops and classes for high school, undergraduate, and graduate students and post-doctoral fellows. An OSU postdoctoral researcher supported by the grant participated in a community outreach event in Wooster, OH to teach elementary school students about the life cycle of mosquitoes.

 


Last Modified: 08/09/2018
Modified by: Peter Piermarini
